title: Adventures with Camille
segmentation: The kinds of things that we want to be able to explain and my concern is with finding explanations for the things that we know about language to the extent that we understand them, that we understand what goes on in language.

When you think about this kind of issue, there are a number of questions that arise.
One is how do we?
How should we actually think about what knowledge of language consists of?

And if you know anything about linguistics, you know that there's a certain amount of controversy about this and the view that I've been taking is, and I prefer to take is one that is at odds with what everybody else thinks.
Almost perversely, so the second question type of question is, what is the architecture of the learner that would explain how is that we come to have this knowledge?

And in that regard there are basically two possibilities when one can break it down a little bit further, but one possibility is that the knowledge that we have about language some of it is actually built into the learner explicitly, and it's there because we find there, because that's because the learner actually has it and the other is that it arises out of the way that the learner.

Is the kind of data that they learn is exposed to in the way that the learner goes about building knowledge of language and there are other types of explanations, but these are basically the two tip the two.

From the architecture of the learner?
So I'm going to very quickly is run through a number of things that I've been involved in, one having to do with what it is that we know when we know language.

This is from my book with Ray Jackendoff called similar syntax where we pursue something that I've come to call the Construction list manifesto, which has a number of different formulations, but I'll explain what that is, and then there's certain kinds of facts that we know about language, and one of the things we have to be able to explain how it is that those.

Those facts are the way they are, how the knowledge of language as we describe it actually ends up in the head of a human being who's acquiring language, and then I'll talk about the the learner, the computational simulation that we've been trying to develop an.
Then I also have a few remarks about simulating language in a social network which has some relevance to the broader questions that I'm talking about.
On the standard view, in linguistic theory, a generative grammar of a language, that is what it is that you know when you know language or representation of what's in your head.
Is an idealized characterization of the linguistic knowledge or linguistic competence of an idealized native speaker, and this is a very classical approach in contemporary linguistic.
Theory and the theory of generative grammar, that is what a possible grammar is, is in term.
In turn, a characterization of possible generative grammars.
Possible things that could be in the heads of native speakers.

The linguistic competence of the native speaker.
And the theory of grammar theory about the language faculty that explains why linguistic competence takes the form that it does.

Both the grammar as described by linguists and the theory of grammar, that is, that this kind of what a possible grammar can be are in some sense in the mind or in the head, and they form a part of the explanation of human linguistic abilities wide.
How it is that we end up knowing what we know.

The alternative view which a lot of people prefer to take very often outside of linguistics, is that what resides in the language faculty is something of quite a different of quite a different sort that reflects in its architecture the dynamical character of language.
In particular, if directly reflects, reflects the fact that grammar is required overtime that it is a psychological mechanism used for speaking and understanding, and that it undergoes.

Change overtime so the view is that is that what we don't have in our heads is some kind of symbolic fixed symbolic device representation which we could call grammar, but rather what we have is our devices that are that are built up overtime that evolve that perform certain kinds of processes and that undergo change.
So the challenge, if we take this alternative view that you really don't have in your head a grammar of the classical sort.

Is that you really do have to account for the linguistic phenomena that have been observed by linguists, so you can throw out the what's known about language simply because you don't like the story that people have told about why it is the way it is.
You have to be able to explain what generative grammar explains, and of course you have to be able to explain more.
You have to be able to explain the acquisition, explain the processing, and explain the change.

And of course this account must explain their dynamical properties as well.
